node.title: South Africa says its Omicron outbreak has peaked
node.alt: A woman and six children wearing face masks walk through a light tunnel in a South African city zoo
node.description: The worst COVID-19-hit country in Africa says it has passed the peak of its fourth wave and is easing restrictions after a stark decline in cases.
node.content:
["While countries around the world continue their battle with Omicron, South Africa believes it\u00a0has reached the end\u00a0of the variant's\u00a0threat.", "In a statement, the government said it believes the country has passed the peak of its fourth COVID-19 wave driven by the Omicron variant.", "A\u00a0midnight to 4am\u00a0curfew on people's movement has\u00a0been lifted with immediate effect.", "The country made the changes based on the trajectory of the pandemic, levels of vaccination in the country and available capacity in the health sector, according to\u00a0Mondli Gungubele, a minister in the presidency.", "South Africa is currently at the lowest of its five-stage COVID-19 alert levels.", "\"All indicators suggest the country may have passed the peak of the fourth wave at a national level,\" a statement from a special cabinet meeting\u00a0said.", "Data from the Department of Health showed a 29.7 per cent decrease in the number of new cases detected in the week ending December\u00a025 compared to the number of cases found in the previous week, at 127,753, the government said.", "South Africa, with close to 3.5 million infections and 91,000 deaths, has been the worst-hit country in Africa during the pandemic on both counts.", "
More restrictions set to ease
", "Besides lifting the restrictions on public movement, the government said gatherings will be restricted to no more than 1,000 people indoors\u00a0and no more than 2,000 people outdoors.", "It also ruled that alcohol shops with licenses to operate beyond 11pm\u00a0may revert back to full license conditions, a welcome boon for traders and businesses hard hit by the pandemic and looking to recover during the festive season.", "\"While the Omicron variant is highly transmissible, there has been lower rates of hospitalisation than in previous waves,\" cabinet said, adding that the wearing of masks in public places remained mandatory.", "Failure to wear a mask in South Africa when required remains a criminal offence.", "Reuters"]
